======= ESSAY CONTEXT =======
DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 5 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Narciso Rodriguez 
from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives 
My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living for a year in a 
furnished one-room apartment, twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria and twenty-seven-year-old 
Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon 
call home. 
In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the 
Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our 
traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared 
cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking 
that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which 
I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of 
childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed 
both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. 
Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that “family” had nothing to do with 
being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, 
Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation 
prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these 
cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of 
honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their 
own kind, were clearly in need. 
Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and first friend), lived above us, and 
Alegria graced our kitchen table for meals more often than not. Also at the table were Sergio 
and Edelmira, my surrogate grandparents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not 
know my “real” grandparents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, until 1970 when they were 
allowed to leave Cuba.) My aunts Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria, and 
Rosemary also all lived nearby and regularly joined us at our table. Countless extended family 
members came and went — and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they 
were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the 
many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us. 
My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the 
language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a 
better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country 
they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters 
while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships. The barriers to work were 
strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind 
of jobs they deserved. In Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had 
studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, 
taking whatever work they could find. The faith that this struggle would lead them and their 
children to better times drove them to endure these hard times. 
I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I’ve often told them that what 
they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I’ve often told them of 
my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I’ve thanked them repeatedly. But, in 
reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at 
such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two 
lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me with their lives, and these 
teachings have been the basis of my life. 
It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to 
this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this 
humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not 
just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of “family.” 
And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I 
learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into 
a home.

ground_truth: The essay effectively addresses the topic of censorship in books, movies, and music, presenting a strong and clear stance against the removal of materials deemed offensive. The content is compelling, with a thought-provoking thesis and well-developed supporting arguments that demonstrate a high level of originality and creative thought. The organization of the essay is commendable, featuring an engaging introduction, well-structured body paragraphs, and smooth transitions that maintain a cohesive flow of ideas. The language and style are vibrant and varied, employing imaginative vocabulary and creative sentence structures that enhance the overall impact of the essay. Additionally, the essay demonstrates strong control over standard writing conventions, with minimal errors that do not impede readability. The conclusion provides a fresh perspective, reinforcing the essay's central argument and leaving the reader with a lasting impression. However, the use of placeholders such as "@CAPS1" and "@CAPS2" disrupts the reading experience, and the essay would benefit from more specific examples and smoother integration of these references. Overall, the essay showcases a high degree of originality, creative expression, and effective communication.
feedback_prediction:
Your essay presents a strong argument against censorship in libraries and other media, bolstered by well-chosen examples and logical reasoning. Your stance is clear and well-articulated, reflecting a deep understanding of the complexities surrounding censorship.

**Strengths:**
1. **Originality and Creativity:** Your essay showcases an original and creative approach to the topic, particularly in how you draw parallels between books, movies, and music. This comparative method effectively highlights the overarching issue of censorship across different media.
2. **Detailed Examples:** The inclusion of specific works like "The @CAPS3 of @ORGANIZATION1" and the discussion about the historical context of language use are insightful. These examples help anchor your argument in real-world instances, making it more compelling.
3. **Engagement:** Your writing style is engaging and captures the reader’s attention. You have a unique voice that shines through, making your argument both personal and persuasive.

**Areas for Improvement:**
1. **Clarity and Organization:** While your ideas are strong, the essay would benefit from clearer transitions between paragraphs and sections. For example, the shift from books to movies to music feels a bit abrupt. Introducing a brief connecting sentence or phrase could enhance the flow.
2. **Grammar and Spelling:** There are several minor grammatical and spelling errors throughout the essay, such as "neccessarily" instead of "necessarily" and "exsisted" instead of "existed." Careful proofreading can help eliminate these distractions. Additionally, correcting placeholders like "@CAPS1" and "@CAPS2" will improve readability.
3. **Sentence Fluency:** Some sentences are a bit lengthy and could be broken down for better readability. For instance, "Movies shouldn't be banned just because it gives a @CAPS15 nightmares or makes them not as emotionally aware of what is right or wrong" could be made more concise.
4. **Stronger Conclusion:** Your conclusion effectively reiterates your main points but could be strengthened by offering a more innovative perspective or a call to action. This would leave a more lasting impression on the reader.

**Suggestions:**
- **Transitions:** To enhance coherence, consider using transitional phrases like "Moreover," "In addition," or "On the other hand" to guide your reader through your points smoothly.
- **Proofreading:** Allocate time to review your essay for minor errors. Reading aloud can often help identify awkward phrasing or mistakes that might be overlooked when reading silently.
- **Expanding Ideas:** Provide a bit more explanation for some of your points. For example, when discussing the historical context of offensive language, delve deeper into why understanding this context is crucial for modern readers.

Overall, your essay demonstrates a solid understanding of the topic and reflects your unique voice and creativity. With some refinement in organization and attention to detail in grammar and spelling, your argument will be even more compelling. Keep pushing the boundaries of your expression and continue to explore new ideas confidently. Excellent work!

STUDENT ESSAY TEXT: Most modern day book, movies, music, etc. do a fairly good job of placing warning in the form of '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' sticks on their covers. But books from before this practice began to happen @MONTH1 be found more offensive then books today. Why? Well, that's because many books of the past use words that today are found offensive. But those books, movies, and music are not at fault like parents try to make it seem. There are examples of how each catagory is in today's society.     Take the book 'The @CAPS3 of @ORGANIZATION1', written by @PERSON1, for example. In that story, there are words that are used to describe people of that time.. Back when @PERSON1 wrote the book, it was perfectly fine to use those words on those people, but in today's modern world, that is a book that has been on the list for being banned. It is offensive to use that word on people today, so parent groups and others are trying to get that book pulled off of shelves in hopes of erasing what was done in the past. I don't believe that a book should be banned for it's content, but rather how well it teaches its reader through its words. If it can teach a student in a high school or college class about the history and the culture of that time, then it shouldn't be banned at all. It should be read.     Movies have a rating system for a reason. There are some movies that are just not meant for a younger audience. People must be of a certain age to rent, buy, or view these kind of movies 'leagally'. Not too many people listen to that system, even though it has exsisted for years. A horror film is not suitable for a @CAPS15 of a young age who believes everything he or she sees on @CAPS4. Movies shouldn't be banned just because it gives a @CAPS15 nightmares or makes them not as emotionally aware of what is right or wrong. That is the fault of the parents. They were the ones who let their @CAPS15 watch that movie in the first place. So the movie shouldn't be held responsible for the @CAPS15. If the movie was intended for a more mature audience, that's the way it should stay.     And that brings us to music. There is a lot of music in today's age that can be considered very offensive. There are only a few 'pure' genres, free of the cursing that is used in many of the others today. But children, teen, and adults all find their favorite kind, and you can't change their minds then. The governement has issued that all music containing harsh words, horrid images to the mind, gruesome scenes, and other elements that are offensive to people, must carry a sticker on it. The black and white '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' sticker. When parents see this sticker on the @CAPS7, @NUM1 download, or whatever their @CAPS15 is using, then they know that it is more than likely not right for their @CAPS15 to listen to. Doesn't mean that the parent is actually going to listen all the time, but it means that there is a slight chance that their minds will not be tainted by 'garbage'.     So, in conclusion, I believe that movies, books, and music that contain 'offensive' material should not be removed from shelves. Just because it is offensive to one person doesn't neccessarily mean that it is the same to another person. There are ratings on things for a reason, to keep children from seeing them and to help with the level of harshness that is given to today's society. People will still argue that books such as 'The @CAPS3 of @ORGANIZATION1', 'The @CAPS3 of @PERSON2', '@CAPS10 in the @CAPS11', and many, many more books like them should be banned. They will always fight that movies such as 'A @CAPS12 on @CAPS13 @CAPS14,' '@DATE1 the @NUM2', or '@CAPS15's @CAPS16' should be removed from store shelves because it gave them nightmares as a @CAPS19 or it gives their @CAPS15 nightmares because they saw it. And they will always try to fight and say that artist like @CAPS17' @CAPS18, @LOCATION1, and @CAPS19 @CAPS20 are not suited for their @CAPS15. Well, this pattern has been going on for years. Those books were made many years before, those movies are intended for a adult audience, not for a @CAPS15 of a young age, and those artists are just trying to make money like everyone else. So when parents try to argue about what should be on shelves and what should not, remember that it might be that parent's fault for letting their @CAPS15 view it in the first place.
TEACHER INSTRUCTION: Please provide feedback on the student's writing in alignment with my values.
FEEDBACK:
baseline_prediction:
### Feedback:

#### Content and Argumentation:
1. **Thesis Statement**: Your essay presents a clear stance on the issue of censoring books, movies, and music. However, the thesis could be more explicitly stated at the beginning to guide the reader through your argument.

2. **Supporting Evidence**: You provide examples from books and movies, but these examples are not fully developed. It would be beneficial to elaborate on specific instances and how they illustrate your point. For example, instead of using placeholders like '@CAPS3 of @ORGANIZATION1', provide real titles and authors to strengthen your argument.

3. **Logical Flow**: Your points on books, movies, and music are somewhat disjointed. Consider using clearer topic sentences and transitions to improve the coherence of your essay.

#### Structure and Organization:
1. **Paragraph Structure**: Each paragraph should start with a clear topic sentence that outlines the main idea. Ensure that all sentences within the paragraph support the topic sentence and contribute to the overall argument.

2. **Conclusion**: The conclusion reiterates your main points well, but it could be more concise. Focus on summarizing your key arguments and reinforcing your thesis.

#### Language and Grammar:
1. **Word Choice**: Be mindful of the words you choose. For example, "leagally" should be "legally," and "exsisted" should be "existed." Proofreading your work can help catch these errors.

2. **Clarity**: Some sentences are confusing due to poor word choice or structure. For instance, "But books from before this practice began to happen @MONTH1 be found more offensive then books today" is unclear. Ensure each sentence clearly conveys your intended meaning.

3. **Grammar and Spelling**: There are multiple grammatical errors, such as "it's" instead of "its," "catagory" instead of "category," and "neccessarily" instead of "necessarily." These mistakes can distract from your argument and should be corrected.

#### Suggestions for Improvement:
1. **Develop Examples**: Replace placeholders with real examples and elaborate on them to strengthen your argument.
2. **Proofread**: Carefully proofread your essay to correct grammatical and spelling errors.
3. **Transitional Phrases**: Use transitional phrases to improve the flow of your argument between paragraphs.
4. **Conciseness**: Be more concise, especially in your conclusion, to ensure your main points are clear and impactful.

Overall, your essay addresses an important issue and presents a clear stance. With more detailed examples, improved coherence, and careful proofreading, your writing will be much stronger. Keep up the good work and continue to refine your skills!

ground_truth: The essay effectively addresses the setting's impact on the cyclist, using specific examples to illustrate how various features, such as the hills, the road signs, and the abandoned grape juice factory, contribute to his challenges and eventual relief. However, the response could benefit from deeper analysis and more detailed exploration of these elements to fully capture their significance. The language is clear, and there is a basic structure in place, but the essay would be more engaging with varied vocabulary and sentence structures. The transitions between ideas are present but could be smoother to enhance the overall flow. Additionally, while the essay stays on topic, there are moments where it could delve deeper into the cyclist's emotional and physical journey to provide a richer narrative. Overall, the response is cohesive and understandable, but it could be more compelling with more vivid language and a more thorough examination of the setting’s effects on the cyclist.
feedback_prediction:
Your essay does a commendable job of identifying specific features of the setting in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" and explaining how they affect the cyclist. I particularly appreciate how you noted the hills, the road sign, and the grape juice advertisement, as these illustrate the challenges and ironies the cyclist faced quite effectively.

**Strengths:**
1. **Specific Examples:** You provided concrete examples from the text, which helps anchor your analysis and makes your argument more compelling.
2. **Clear Structure:** Your essay has a clear structure, guiding the reader through the different aspects of the setting that affected the cyclist.
3. **Engaging Language:** The use of phrases like "exasperated the cyclist" and "sadistic irony" adds a level of engagement and shows an effort to use varied vocabulary.

**Areas for Improvement:**
1. **Depth of Analysis:** While you mentioned several features that affect the cyclist, some of your points could benefit from deeper exploration. For instance, consider elaborating on how the hills specifically impacted his physical and mental endurance. How did the "water-depleting" pace affect his overall journey?
2. **Integration of Quotes:** When integrating quotes, aim for a smoother transition and ensure they enhance your argument. The quote about the speed limit, for example, could be more seamlessly woven into your analysis to highlight how the cyclist's slow pace contributed to his frustration and exhaustion.
3. **Conclusion:** Your concluding sentence could be more impactful and reflective. Perhaps summarize how these negative experiences contributed to the cyclist’s growth or his overall journey, tying back to the main theme of perseverance and resilience.

**Grammatical and Stylistic Notes:**
1. **Use of Vocabulary:** You have a good command of vocabulary, but there's room to incorporate even more varied and imaginative language to make your essay more vibrant.
2. **Minor Errors:** Be mindful of minor grammatical errors, such as "exasperated" instead of "exacerbated." Proofreading your essay can help catch these small mistakes.

**Overall:**
Your essay is clear and well-organized, with solid evidence from the text to support your points. By delving deeper into your analysis and refining the integration of quotes, you can elevate the originality and depth of your response, fully aligning with our class’s emphasis on creative expression and originality. Keep taking those creative risks in your writing—your unique voice is your greatest asset!

Feel free to come and discuss your ideas with me if you need further guidance or want to delve deeper into the text. Great job, and keep pushing the boundaries of your creative expression!
llm_prompt:
TASK: The goal is to generate feedback for a highlighted passage (STUDENT ESSAY TEXT) from a student's essay as if it were written by the teacher. Provide feedback that is aligned with the teacher's style and the class needs. Use all of the information at your disposable to customize to the teacher and class. Take the teacher instruction into account, in case they emphasize specifically what they want you to do.

---------------------------

----- TEACHER PERSONA -----
Here is a persona of the teacher. Use this to help with impersonating them when writing feedback.

----- UPDATED TEACHER PERSONA -----
As an educator, my highest priority is to nurture and cultivate each student's ability to express themselves creatively and originally through their writing. I aim to provide an environment that encourages innovative thinking and rewards unique ideas, helping students feel confident in developing and presenting their thoughts in a way that showcases their individuality and imaginative perspectives. My teaching style is anchored in fostering originality and creative expression, creating a space where students are encouraged to take risks in their writing and explore new ideas without fear of judgment. 

I prioritize constructive feedback that inspires further thought and creativity, highlighting their unique and imaginative contributions before offering suggestions for improvement. My feedback focuses on clarity, effective organization, and the development of arguments, while also emphasizing the importance of varied and imaginative language. I strive to be approachable and supportive, engaging with students as individuals, understanding their unique perspectives, and encouraging them to express those perspectives confidently.

My feedback is tailored to each student's specific strengths and areas for growth, with a particular emphasis on enhancing their creative voice and ensuring grammatical accuracy. I value dialogue, inviting students to discuss their ideas with me and their peers, facilitating a collaborative and dynamic learning experience. I encourage students to build on their personal perspectives and experiences, ensuring their writing is both original and engaging.

Ultimately, my goal is to nurture an environment where creativity flourishes, original thinking is celebrated, and students feel empowered to push the boundaries of their expression. I aim to help students refine their writing by focusing on the clarity of their arguments, the coherence of their structure, and the originality of their ideas, all while maintaining a supportive and encouraging atmosphere.



----- FEEDBACK -----
Here are examples of feedback the teacher has given to students.

======= FEEDBACK EXAMPLE =======
STUDENT ESSAY TEXT: The author concludes the story with a statement that makes you think because she wants to emphasize the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus. Just like Saeng, the hibiscus is in a new environment and has to adapt to the surroundings. Saeng had just failed her driving test so shes bummed about that. The concluding sentance makes you realize that Saeng can overcome her driving challenges if the plant can overcome the harsh surroundings.

TEACHER FEEDBACK: The essay attempts to discuss the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus, but it lacks depth and fails to capture the essence of the story. The ideas are underdeveloped and the content is minimal, which makes it difficult for the reader to fully grasp the intended message. There is a noticeable absence of specific examples from the story to support the points being made, which weakens the overall argument. The response also tends to wander off-topic and does not adhere closely to the prompt. The language used is simplistic and riddled with grammatical errors, such as "shes" instead of "she's" and "sentance" instead of "sentence." These errors distract from the readability of the essay and hinder its effectiveness. Additionally, the essay lacks a coherent structure, with ideas presented in a disjointed manner that makes the narrative difficult to follow. To improve, the writer should focus on providing detailed support from the story, maintaining clarity in addressing the prompt, enhancing vocabulary, and ensuring a smooth flow of ideas with proper transitions.

You have economic loss from the electric bill, health loss because you won't be able to exercise as much, and community less because you won't spen as much with your community. Financial loss is something that many people are concerned

TEACHER FEEDBACK: The essay presents a clear and focused argument against excessive computer use, supported by recognizable main ideas: financial loss, health issues, and community disintegration. The originality of the thesis could be improved by providing a more unique or thought-provoking perspective on the topic. The essay is satisfactorily organized, with a basic introduction, body, and conclusion, though the transitions between paragraphs could be smoother to enhance the flow of ideas. The word choice effectively conveys the intended message, but there is room for more varied and imaginative language to make the essay more engaging. The sentences generally flow well, though some constructions could be more fluid and varied to maintain the reader’s interest. The essay demonstrates control of standard writing conventions, but there are noticeable errors in spelling and grammar that slightly impede readability. Overall, the essay is clear and persuasive but could benefit from more creative expression and polished language use to fully align with the teacher's emphasis on originality and creative expression.

by Joe Kurmaskie 
FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece 
of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers 
who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It’s not that a group of 
old guys doesn’t know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid 
place. Things change. 
At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer 
evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn’t have done was 
let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice 
and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to 
Yosemite National Park. 
They’d sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I 
would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with 
strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” 
This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but 
on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water 
supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool 
pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. 
Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, 
and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had 
been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of 
California in June. 
I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my 
strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the 
neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water 
wouldn’t cool down. It didn’t matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. 
The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make 
that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. 
Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was 
replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign 
jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. 
The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so 
cruel. 
I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it 
really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased 
past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. 
The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my 
shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June 
simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades, 
caused me to laugh. 
It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. 
There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride 
down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d 
be fine. 
Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make 
sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst 
of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. 
In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years 
earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A 
sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still 
be seen. 
I hung my head. 
That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating 
brain. 
I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. 
I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you 
have left to circulate. With any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. 
It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some 
expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and 
their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I 
was going to lose consciousness for the last time. 
Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining 
elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear 
were all behind me. 
GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE’RE 
YOUR BEST BET! 
“And the only bet,” I remember thinking. 
As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an 
overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even 
though I didn’t own a rod or reel. 
An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from 
my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. 
“Where you headed in such a hurry?” 
“Yosemite,” I whispered. 
“Know the best way to get there?” 
I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group 
I’d listened to in Lodi. 
“Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” 
And I promised myself right then that I’d always stick to it in the future.

Dear [Student's Name],

Thank you for submitting your essay "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit." You have done a commendable job in identifying and discussing how different features of the setting affect the cyclist. Here are some points to help you further improve your writing:

1. **Introduction and Conclusion:**
   - **Introduction:** Your essay could benefit from a more robust introduction that provides context for the reader and states the thesis clearly. For example, you could introduce the essay's main themes and how the setting influences the cyclist's journey.

2. **Clarity and Specificity:**
   - **Details:** When you mention certain features, such as the "hills" and the "sun," try to be more specific about how they affect the cyclist. For example, "The steep hills and the relentless sun significantly drained the cyclist's energy and morale."

I was doing a water-depleting @NUM2," you could say, “The cyclist struggled to maintain speed, noting the irony in the ‘Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit’ sign as he could barely pedal at @NUM2 mph.”

3. **Grammar and Word Choice:**
   - **Exasperated vs. Exacerbated:** Use "exacerbated" instead of "exasperated" in the context of worsening the cyclist's condition.
   - **Word Choice:** Avoid repetitive phrases like "probably felt" and "probably made him feel." They can be replaced with more assertive language to convey the impact more confidently.

4. **Flow and Coherence:**

5. **Analysis and Insight:**

Overall, the essay does not meet the standards for originality, creative expression, or imaginative language use as outlined in the guidelines.
feedback_prediction:
Your essay provides a good starting point in exploring how the features of the setting affect the cyclist during his journey. You’ve identified various elements like the road conditions, the presence of rocks, and potential encounters with snakes, which are all relevant to the cyclist's experience. This shows that you have a clear understanding of the text and its setting, which is a strong foundation.

However, to enhance your essay and make it more engaging, here are a few suggestions:

1. **Expand Your Examples**: While you’ve mentioned some features like the road and rocks, it would be beneficial to delve deeper into specific examples from the text. For instance, you could describe how the cyclist's water supply depleting in the high desert affected his journey, or how the abandoned Welch’s Grape Juice factory he encountered added to his despair.

2. **Organize Your Ideas**: Structuring your essay into distinct paragraphs can help improve readability. You might begin with an introduction that briefly outlines the main challenges faced by the cyclist, followed by separate paragraphs that elaborate on each point with supporting evidence from the text.

3. **Clarify and Refine Your Language**: There are a few areas where refining your vocabulary and sentence structures could enhance clarity and interest. For example, instead of saying "the road, the rocks everything close," you could say "the treacherous road conditions and the sharp, scattered rocks." This not only provides more vivid imagery but also makes your writing more engaging.

4. **Grammatical Accuracy**: Pay attention to grammar and punctuation to ensure your ideas are communicated clearly. For instance, "That why its important for a cyclist to never listen to anyone but themselves" should be corrected to "That's why it's important for a cyclist to trust their own instincts."

5. **Engage with the Text's Themes**: Reflect on how the setting not only poses physical challenges but also tests the cyclist’s mental and emotional endurance. This will add depth to your analysis and show a nuanced understanding of the text.

Here's a revised version of your paragraph to illustrate these suggestions:

"The features of the setting profoundly impact the cyclist in many ways. The rough terrain, with its sharp rocks and unpredictable conditions, poses significant physical challenges. For instance, the cyclist's encounter with a large snake blocking the road and the discovery of an abandoned ghost town highlight the isolation and danger of the journey. Moreover, the high desert heat and the scarcity of drinkable water test his endurance and resourcefulness. These examples underscore the importance of self-reliance for a cyclist, as relying on outdated or misguided advice can lead to perilous situations. This is why cyclists often stay close to well-traveled roads where help is readily available should they encounter trouble."

Overall, your essay captures the essence of the cyclist's struggle with his environment. With some additional development and refinement, your writing will become even more compelling and insightful. Keep pushing the boundaries of your expression, and remember, your unique perspective is your greatest strength

----- TEACHER PERSONA -----
Here is a persona of the teacher. Use this to help with impersonating them when writing feedback.

----- UPDATED TEACHER PERSONA -----
As an educator, my highest priority is to nurture and cultivate each student's ability to express themselves creatively and originally through their writing. I aim to provide an environment that encourages innovative thinking and rewards unique ideas, helping students feel confident in developing and presenting their thoughts in a way that showcases their individuality and imaginative perspectives. My teaching style is anchored in fostering originality and creative expression, creating a space where students are encouraged to take risks in their writing and explore new ideas without fear of judgment. 

I prioritize constructive feedback that inspires further thought and creativity, highlighting their unique and imaginative contributions before offering suggestions for improvement. My feedback focuses on clarity, effective organization, and the development of arguments, while also emphasizing the importance of varied and imaginative language. I strive to be approachable and supportive, engaging with students as individuals, understanding their unique perspectives, and encouraging them to express those perspectives confidently.

My feedback is tailored to each student's specific strengths and areas for growth, with a particular emphasis on enhancing their creative voice and ensuring grammatical accuracy. I value dialogue, inviting students to discuss their ideas with me and their peers, facilitating a collaborative and dynamic learning experience. I encourage students to build on their personal perspectives and experiences, ensuring their writing is both original and engaging.

Ultimately, my goal is to nurture an environment where creativity flourishes, original thinking is celebrated, and students feel empowered to push the boundaries of their expression. I aim to help students refine their writing by focusing on the clarity of their arguments, the coherence of their structure, and the originality of their ideas, all while maintaining a supportive and encouraging atmosphere.

baseline_prediction:
FEEDBACK:

Thank you for your essay. I can see that you have put thought into how a cyclist needs to be aware of their surroundings. However, there are several areas you could improve:

1. **Clarity and Coherence**: Your essay could benefit from clearer organization. Try to structure your ideas in a more logical order. For instance, first discuss the various features that affect cyclists, then explain the importance of being aware of these features. 

2. **Detail and Examples**: While you mention several factors that can affect a cyclist, such as roads, rocks, and snakes, it would be helpful to expand on these points with more detailed examples or explanations. For instance, explain how rough terrain specifically affects cycling.

3. **Grammar and Punctuation**: There are several grammatical errors and incomplete sentences that need attention. For example, "For example the road, the rocks everything close." could be revised to "For example, the road, the rocks, and everything nearby can affect the cyclist." Also, "That why its important" should be "That's why it's important."

4. **Pronoun Consistency**: Be consistent with pronoun usage. You shift between "he" and "they". Pick one and stick to it throughout the essay to maintain clarity.

5. **Misconceptions**: The line "That why its important for a cyclist to never listen to anyone but themselves" might be misleading. Cyclists often need to heed advice from experienced cyclists, maps, or even safety instructions. Consider revising this to emphasize the importance of being self-reliant while also staying informed.

6. **Safety and Context**: When you mention that cyclists are often seen on roads with cars, it’s important to clarify the context. Stress the importance of safety and being visible to others on the road, and perhaps mention the value of wearing protective gear like helmets.

Here is a revised version of your essay with these suggestions incorporated:

---

The features of the environment affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the road conditions, nearby rocks, and other environmental factors can significantly impact the ride. A cyclist needs to be fully aware of their surroundings because if they are not, they can encounter problems along the way, such as encountering snakes, navigating rough terrain, or avoiding rocks in their path. 

That's why it's important for a cyclist to be well-prepared and informed about their route. While self-reliance is crucial, cyclists should also take advice from reliable sources and use appropriate tools like maps and safety guidelines. 

When you often see cyclists on roads shared with cars, it is important to remember that this choice is made for visibility and safety. Cyclists need to ensure they are visible to drivers and are following traffic rules to minimize risks. Wearing protective gear, such as helmets and reflective clothing, further enhances their safety on busy roads.

---

Keep up the good work, and keep refining your writing skills!

The essay lacks creativity in its flow of ideas, making it difficult to follow. There is little to no imaginative vocabulary or sentence structure, and the writing does not demonstrate control of standard writing conventions. Overall, the essay needs significant improvement in clarity, structure, content, and language to meet the desired criteria of originality and creative expression.

======= ESSAY CONTEXT =======
DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 3 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit 
by Joe Kurmaskie 
FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece 
of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers 
who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It’s not that a group of 
old guys doesn’t know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid 
place. Things change. 
At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer 
evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn’t have done was 
let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice 
and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to 
Yosemite National Park. 
They’d sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I 
would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with 
strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” 
This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but 
on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water 
supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool 
pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. 
Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, 
and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had 
been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of 
California in June. 
I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my 
strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the 
neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water 
wouldn’t cool down. It didn’t matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. 
The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make 
that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. 
Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was 
replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign 
jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. 
The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so 
cruel. 
I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it 
really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased 
past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. 
The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my 
shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June 
simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades, 
caused me to laugh. 
It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. 
There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride 
down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d 
be fine. 
Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make 
sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst 
of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. 
In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years 
earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A 
sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still 
be seen. 
I hung my head. 
That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating 
brain. 
I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. 
I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you 
have left to circulate. With any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. 
It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some 
expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and 
their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I 
was going to lose consciousness for the last time. 
Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining 
elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear 
were all behind me. 
GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE’RE 
YOUR BEST BET! 
“And the only bet,” I remember thinking. 
As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an 
overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even 
though I didn’t own a rod or reel. 
An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from 
my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. 
“Where you headed in such a hurry?” 
“Yosemite,” I whispered. 
“Know the best way to get there?” 
I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group 
I’d listened to in Lodi. 
“Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” 
And I promised myself right then that I’d always stick to it in the future.

DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 4 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Winter Hibiscus 
by Minfong Ho 
Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng
walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist
shop to see if the plant can be purchased. 
It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat
leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in
seemingly random profusion. 
“Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy
potted plant by the corner. 
There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals
splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of
recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1 
“Saebba,” Saeng whispered. 
A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with
vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into
the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the
bucket. 
Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes,
oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had
not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world. 
When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and
cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. 
And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with
purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to
see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick
walls or between tiled roofs. 
And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and
found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it.
“Dok Malik,” she said,
savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its
tag, “jasmine.” 
One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed
her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could
almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she
combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng
would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it. 
Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm
around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed
comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? 
A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a
channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone. 
And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept. 
It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the
last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk.
As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of
the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to
her. 
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully.
“Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed
the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind. 
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where
did you get it?” 
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question. 
“How much?” 
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins. 
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the 
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .” 
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said. 
“Then what else—?” 
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.” 
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this
vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed
the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. 
“What happened?” she asked, more gently. 
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. 
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the
eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. 
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful
plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” 
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. 
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the
words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said. 
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t
as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.
That’s what matters.” 
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her
other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.” 
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The
soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair
trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There
was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply. 
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her. 
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and
start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?” 
“I’d love it,” Saeng said. 
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it.
She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl,
the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth
watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not
even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue.
But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac. 
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it.
Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng
now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange
before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her
now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against
the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. 
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the
geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.

Your essay does a commendable job of capturing the warm and familial atmosphere that Narciso Rodriguez creates in his memoir. The organization of your paragraphs, each focusing on different aspects of Rodriguez's life and the mood he portrays, shows a clear structure and logical progression in your ideas. You've effectively highlighted the vivid imagery Rodriguez uses to depict his childhood home, neighborhood, and the sacrifices of his parents, which indeed creates a touching narrative.

However, let's elevate your essay further by incorporating more originality and deeper analysis. Here are some suggestions:

1. **Engage More Deeply with the Text**: While you’ve done well to outline the main points, try to delve deeper into how these elements interact to establish the mood. For instance, how does the Cuban music and cuisine specifically contribute to the sense of comfort and belonging? Elaborate on how the cultural diversity in his neighborhood not only reflects kindness but also resilience and unity, especially in the face of overt racism and segregation.

2. **Enhance Your Creative Expression**: Your essay would benefit from a more varied and imaginative use of language. Experiment with more descriptive adjectives and vivid verbs to bring your narrative to life. For example, instead of saying "he described his childhood home," you might write "Rodriguez vividly transports us to his childhood haven, where the air was perfumed with the rich aromas of Cuban cuisine and the rhythmic beats of passionate music."

3. **Strengthen Transitions and Flow**: While your essay is well-organized, consider using more transitional phrases to ensure a smoother flow between paragraphs. Phrases like "Moreover," "In addition," or "Furthermore" can help guide the reader through your arguments seamlessly.

4. **Refine Your Conclusion**: The conclusion is clear and touches on all the points discussed, but it can be more impactful. Summarize not just that the article is pleasing to read and touches the heart, but also reflect on the broader implications of Rodriguez's narrative. How does his story of family, sacrifice, and community resonate with or inspire the reader?

5. **Proofread for Minor Errors**: There are minor grammatical errors such as "Narciso described," which should be "Narciso describes," to maintain consistency in tense. Also, ensure correct punctuation and capitalization throughout.

In essence, your essay has strong foundational elements, and with a bit of fine-tuning and a more creative approach, it can truly shine. I’m excited to see how you further develop your unique voice and analytical skills. Keep pushing the boundaries of your expression!

Feel free to discuss any of these points further if you need additional guidance.

DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 5 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Narciso Rodriguez 
from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives 
My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living for a year in a 
furnished one-room apartment, twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria and twenty-seven-year-old 
Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon 
call home. 
In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the 
Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our 
traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared 
cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking 
that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which 
I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of 
childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed 
both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. 
Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that “family” had nothing to do with 
being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, 
Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation 
prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these 
cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of 
honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their 
own kind, were clearly in need. 
Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and first friend), lived above us, and 
Alegria graced our kitchen table for meals more often than not. Also at the table were Sergio 
and Edelmira, my surrogate grandparents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not 
know my “real” grandparents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, until 1970 when they were 
allowed to leave Cuba.) My aunts Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria, and 
Rosemary also all lived nearby and regularly joined us at our table. Countless extended family 
members came and went — and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they 
were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the 
many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us. 
My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the 
language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a 
better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country 
they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters 
while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships. The barriers to work were 
strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind 
of jobs they deserved. In Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had 
studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, 
taking whatever work they could find. The faith that this struggle would lead them and their 
children to better times drove them to endure these hard times. 
I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I’ve often told them that what 
they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I’ve often told them of 
my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I’ve thanked them repeatedly. But, in 
reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at 
such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two 
lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me with their lives, and these 
teachings have been the basis of my life. 
It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to 
this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this 
humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not 
just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of “family.” 
And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I 
learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into 
a home.

Thank you for your effort in writing this essay. You have done a good job in capturing the essence of Narciso Rodriguez's memoir and the various elements that contribute to the pleasant and familial atmosphere he describes. Below are some areas where you can improve to make your writing even stronger:

1. **Introduction and Thesis Statement:**
